PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: Mrs. M. Alexander Richardson
Address: Bullfrog
Birthplace: North Denver, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? At my father's
Where had you been living before that? In any father's house in Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 1/2 mile at the Post Office & Woods
How often could a visit be made to the store? When we went for mail about once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
We found groceries expensive here & when the men went to Prince Albert most of the groceries were bought there. Tea, coffee, sugar, spices. We had a long list & could get nearly any necessary article.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Red Wing
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs. milled in Kidd's Mill
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 1/2 mile
What year? 1907-1908
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 50¢
What other grain products did you use? Forget the price
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, before 1904
How did you grind it? At a neighbor's crushing mill
Prior to 1904 when the Railway came to Melfort I lived on a farm, since then I have lived in town and have been close to stores. Since then we have been able to get anything needed.
1. INTERROGATORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1894.

Where did you set up housekeeping? In Medicine Hat, Alta., Mrs. Ruth.

Where had you been living before that? ... In any other place, here or abroad?

For how many people did you prepare meals? 3.

How far was it to your nearest store? N.W. Hotel, Alta., Mrs. Ruth.

How often could a visit be made to this store? Weekly, Mrs. Ruth.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Coffee, sugar, flour, salt, tea, etc.

In what quantities did you buy these? Coffee, sugar, flour, salt, tea, etc.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $5.50 p.a.

How much did you use graham flour?

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally? Yes, Mrs. Ruth.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Rolladoats Sonny.

What other grain products did you use? Forget the price.

Gormealt? Whole Wheat? Farina?

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, Mrs. Ruth.

How did you grind it? At a grinding mill.

Prior to 1904 when the Railway came to Calgary I lived on a farm, since then I have lived in town and have been close to stores, since then I have been able to get anything.
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 pounds.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $6.00.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Imperial.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.
At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Milking cows.
What kind of butter did you make? Butter.
What was the price of butter? $1.50 per lb.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
Did you make cheese? Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, Pork, Prairie chicken, Partridge, Chicken.
How did you get fresh meat? Killed & bought.
How often did you get fresh meat? After 1922 there was a butcher shop.
How did you preserve meat? Fresh pork, salted pork.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Sometimes.
What kinds? Deer, moose, bear.
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? When the men took time off to go fishing we had fish.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh caught.
Kinds? Jack fish, suckers.
We frequently net fished with a chicken wire net on a pole in the stream running past our house on the farm.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black. At what price? $1.00.
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Blend.
Price? $2.00. What other beverages were used? Milk.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? No.
If not, where from? Potatoes grown by a farmer gave them to anyone needing potatoes.
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of?
Potatoes, cabbage, carrots, onions, turnips, beets.
We have always grown sufficient for our own use.
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? By the half lot.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the half lot.
What weight? How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?
What was the price of prunes?
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
Raisins + currants

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.
Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons? Other foods?
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1928.
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1928.
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1928.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes, I try to make enough fruit jam to last the year.
To what extent? I can what vegetables don't keep very well.
Did you make your own vinegar? Not all, I bought acetic acid and diluted it with water.
6. What kind of tea did you buy? ...Black tea ...Was it what price? ...$1.50 per lb.

7. Vegetables and canned fruits

   - What kind of potatoes did you buy? ...White potatoes ...Was it what price? ...$1.25 per lb.

   - What other vegetables did you buy? ...Carrots ...Was it what price? ...$0.50 per lb.

   - What kind of canned fruits did you buy? ...Applesauce ...Was it what price? ...$1.00 per can

8. Preserving

   In the early years did you preserve any foods by freezing? ...Yes

   Other foods? ...Corn ...Was it what price? ...$0.50 per lb.

   That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ...1940

   That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ...1940

   Do you still preserve foods by canning or freezing? ...Yes

   To what extent? ...I try to freeze vegetables when I have them in abundance.

   Did you make your own vinegar? ...Not all I got acetate acid and diluted it with water
When our town started in 1902, a number of those things were freighted in but when the Railway came in 1904, I don't think there is anything named that did not appear on shelves except dried corn. Nearly everything was weighed by clerk.

I don't remember prices. Wild fruit grew in abundance such as Saskatoons, strawberries, raspberries, pin cherries, black currants, high bush cranberries.

Cultivated rhubarb always done well. Having those fruits we did not look for other things. We missed the apples but they were shipped in in barrels from Ontario.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Cakes
Did you make yeast for your own use? No
Using hops? Salt rising?
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? Yes
Did you make your own baking powder? No
Our town started in 1902, a number of these things were freighted in April when the railway came in 1904. I don't think there was anything named Lily white syrup that did not appear in shelves. Every thing was weighed by clerk.

I don't remember prices.

Wild fruit grew in abundance such as raspberries, strawberries, black currants, high bush cranberries, blueberries, gooseberries, cultivated rhubarb always done well having those fruits we did not look for other things. We missed the apples but they were shipped in barrels from Ontario.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Coated
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes
Using hops? No
Salt rising? Yes
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Cream of tartar? Yes
Did you make your own baking soda? Yes

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) Stoney creek which has its source at Eagle Lake.

How far was this water from your home? Creek ran through farm.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Pails & barrels.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We used a lot of soft water.

Water supply for town now is from this creek. It was fitted in. We had town water from 1912. First supply came from a well but did not prove sufficient.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did not exist water for drinking and for cooking (well, river, cistern, dugout).

How far was this water from your home? (well, barrel, tank)

Here was it brought to the house? (well, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

Water supply for town now is from this creek.

It was piped in. We had town water from 1912.

First supply came from a well but did not prove sufficient
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? I made soap for laundry.

If you used your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer sell? Royal Brown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood, white coal.

Where did you get your fuel? Local land which we wanted to break. Later, that was done. Went about 70 miles.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

When land was taken up, wood got more expensive, and we built our large home in town in 1907. We had a furnace & used wood for a while & about 1914 started coal. In 1950 I have had oil installed.

In 1909 we installed a soft water pressure system & had bath & cesspool, shower system.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) My husband started to be.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

Had an old stone which did for a while.

By whom was your first cook stove made? The clergy.

What year was it purchased? 1904. Price? $95.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

Galvanized water pails, iron frying pans, tin milk pails.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

Enamel dishes.

When did you first see enamel ware? As long as I can remember.

Aluminum? In 1922. An agent put on a demonstration of aluminum ware & he gave me a frying pan and I still use it, as well as a wear-lube pint dipper.

This was in my home in town.

I find aluminum satisfactory.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Describe any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers associated with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Elders used to weigh nearly everything but now most things come packaged. I remember being fed by the chick.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Summer - Winter - Whole Wheat or Rolled Oat Porridge, Milk, Bread, Coffee, Cream, Butter, Sugar.
Dinner: Fried Pork, Potatoes, Vegetables various kinds.
Year: Always Sugar. In winter Roasts of meat, Chicken + nearly always dessert, rice, Bread pudding, Buttermilk pie etc.
Supper: Fried Potatoes, Bread, Cake, Home canned fruit.
Father, Mother, 2 children, Allen, Lillie I.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I can't remember menu, but anyway we had a good meal. I think we must have had turkey because I raised turkeys in 1901-1902. We also had Christmas pudding.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never, no never.

If a person had any ambition they would never come to near starving because as I have told, things grew in abundance. Cattle had free range + anybody could make a start, in stock + other farm animals. A young pig would cost about $5.00 + it could be fed on scraps + chops.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Section any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Clarks used to weigh nearly everything but now most things come packaged. It was all bagged for us by the clerk.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Summer/Winter whole wheat or rolled oat porridge, milk, bread, coffee, cream, butter, sugar.

Dinner: Fried pork, potatoes, vegetable various kinds, tea, cream, sugar. In winter roasts of meat, chicken & nearly dessert, rice, bread pudding. Buttermilk pie etc.

Supper: Fried potatoes, bread, cake, home canned fruit.

Father, mother, 2 children, Allen, Lillie I.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I can't remember menu, but anyway we had a good meal. I think we must have had turkey because I raised turkeys in 1901-1902. We also had Christmas pudding.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never, no never. If a person had any ambition they would never come to near starving because as I have told, things grew in abundance. Cattle had free range & anybody could make a start, in stock & other farm animals. A young pig would cost about $5.00 & it could be fed on scraps & chop.
17. What did you serve at your first Christmas dinner in eastern Kansas?

But any way we had a good meal.

I think we must have had turkey because I raised turkeys in 1901-1902.

We also had Christmas puddings.

If a person had any ambition they would never come to mean starving because as I have told, things grew in abundance.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Very little difference. If there was anything we thought we would like & could not get it, we just done without and did not feel bad about it.

There are pressure cookers today which can cook a meal in less time. I still use a wood & coal stove.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homesteaded and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We have always had a garden & only purchased canned goods when our supply of home grown was used.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

J.R. Aikenhead

Peter Aikenhead,

My Husband & his father homesteaded here in 1892 and I never heard any complaint about shortages of things to eat. There was 10 children and all were content & happy when my father & his family came in 1900 & we never felt any hardship.

We never expected any help from Govt like folks do now a day. Everyone done all they could to make home.
We have always had a garden + not only purchased canned goods when our supply of home grown was used.

A.R. Atkinson
